posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9517761
>What about link cable support on GB/C/A games? Can you demonstrate this feature while paired with an original console? No!

For the GB/GBC, yes. The cores support it over the SNAC connection and there are SNAC cables for it.

For GBA currently no, the core does not support it yet, but the hardware is capable if the core got updated to support it.

>What about utilizing custom chips on cartridges to expand features on consoles?

It currently supports every expansion chip except those two SNES Mahjong games that had ARM co-processors on them. It even supports the SPC-7110 games, something not even SNES flashcarts support, and the homebrew "custom" SNES expansion chips like the MSU-1 or the additional custom hardware in the Atari 7800 version of Rikki and Vikki, of which only a single software emulator is able to run.... and only because the developer of the game made that emulator specifically to run his game on PCs.

I had exactly the same experience, it's very fiddly and annoying to build. Especially that not where you have to drop the nuts down that weird hole then try and screw the bolt in and grasp the nut and permanently lock it in. Not as erotic as it sounds. There were also a few holes that still had material in. Had to drill out one completely. The buttons weren't quite long enough so had to glue some card shims on. Basically, lots of little problems that aren't deal breakers on their own but together make it super annoying and not worth the money.
But that's just the case. The board itself is a completely different story, it's really nicely laid out, some cool features other boards don't have (I like the SCART connector even if it's a stupid thing to put on instead of a Saturn-style DIN, the hdmi switches helped solved a problem with syncing and not having ports on every face means you can actually put it in an AV rack.
On the whole I'm happy with it, though. It gets far more use than any other retro system/emulsion box/whatever you want to call it.

>>9520506

>>9521590
Input lag can definitely be a perceptible problem, but there's both people who dramatically oversell its existence, prominence, and impact, as well as those trying to pretend that it's actually nothing.
In truth, input lag can vary widely for a very large amount of different reasons, given how different games work differently, different displays work differently, and different software emulators and hardware emulators differ amongst each other as well as original hardware, along with potential settings, there's hundreds of variables determining what kind of input lag you can be looking at. In many cases it truly isn't perceptible, others may be subtly perceptible, and some where it has an appreciable impact on the player's experience without them having to be a turbo-autistic speedrunner who can do arbitrary code execution in their sleep.
It's cumulative.

https://youtu.be/b3tbcUszA2s?t=515

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9521525
You're right, I can get used to it, but why would when there are solutions for mitigating it and in other cases completely eliminating it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9521749
I appreciate what the section of the video you linked demonstrates which justifies some of my own research and adds merit to what people have taught me from different retro gaming communities. This is why I am really interested in the MiSTer and frequently visit my locals to play the one they set up since I can't afford my own yet. The FPGA itself doesn't have any lag; and disregarding how accurate the core is, so the program gets sent out as is. Further down the pipeline is where the potential accumulative lag begins to be introduced.

>Input Device
You can either use the direct serial port to interface original hardware via SNAC. Direct serial has no inherent lag, but even an OEM controller might have some, yet not enough that you won't notice. USB on the other hand has to translate your inputs at the OS level which might add delay but nowhere near half a frame so it is up to you to choose a device that has an encoder with the least amount of delay.

see:
MiSTer Input Latency Database [full detailed sheet linked on the page]
https://rpubs.com/misteraddons/inputlatency

>Game itself
Some games have a different kind of delay due to how the programmer affixed the sprite flow and input command as well as other underlying programming variables which might cause undesirable performance. Some of these inconsistencies can be fixed or changed by the community as needed.

>Display
In my opinion, playing over a CRT display is the optimal way to play the MiSTer. There are plenty of options that will suit people of all budgets. As for digital displays, you have an abundance of choice and you will get the best results with a "gaming" monitor designed to provide the least amount of lag.

Or, you can just buy each console you want to play for peace of mind that you are experiencing the game as originally intended.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9525380
>Who is the target audience for the mister?
The mistake a lot of people make is that they view the MiSTer FPGA project like a commercial product (i.e Analogue) when in fact it's just an enthusiast venture. The only people making immediate profit off of the project are the people selling pre-built add-ons for the DE-10 Nano to be used with the MiSTer FPGA project, and of course Terasic for each DE-10 Nano unit sold. Sorg, the main developer, is not directly profiting off this project, but he does accept donations which is a huge difference from providing services for pay. Some add-on sellers do state on their website that a portion of each sale will be donated to Sorg so this kind of transparency shows which sellers we should be buying from as well if you don't plan to build your own add-ons.

Most vocal people in the "just emulate for free" category don't actually provide any solid arguments or convincing points to add weight to their posts so I would prefer to disregard them.

There is a surprising amount of people in the MiSTer FPGA community who already have hardware collections and are convinced they can sell parts of their collections with no regrets. The biggest contributing factors to why most haven't pulled the trigger is sentimental value as well as trying to hold on for huge returns in the collector's market. As for people who do have hardware collections plus a CRT and aren't interested in the MiSTer, they are fine where they are because they are not in search of a solution to replicate what they can already do now.

>Has anyone tried out the AO486 core?
It's in the middleground between setting up real hardware and virtual machines as far as involvement goes, but it's a lot closer to setting up a virtual machine. I have not used external accessories besides mouse and keyboard, but I believe it does support Real-Time Clock and definitely MIDI.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9527078
The casual/mainstream market never sees value in specialized hardware, they're too obsessed with convenience and abundance to care about the benefits. Most casuals don't want to have the headaches of worrying about things like accuracy or input timing and are quick to dismiss any discrepancies they think are irrelevant, they just need the game to run and that's it. Software emulation and MiSTer may be visually difficult to distinguish under several circumstances to the average person such as color output or ability to render the game in sync with everything else. The line can be tough to draw for most on which is better because the FPGA-based emulators have quickly caught up and even exceeded it's cycle accurate software counterparts in many technical areas. For any applicable cores, MiSTer has more accurate sound (certified against MDfourier). Most importantly, no core has input delay that isn't native to the original game or hardware, something all software emulators still haven't nailed down without the use of run-ahead (banned on speedrun). Input delay is always a subject easily dismissed by the typical casual because you're not practicing a game enough to begin to care about getting optimal input timings in, you just need to play your game and that's it. If you're only concerned that the game runs as best as it could outside of using original hardware, I don't see why having all these options for different budgets hurts.

>>9523335
DOOM came so very close to the first one. They could have given the pistol perfect accuracy and given a damage boost so every shot does the equivalent of two chaingun rounds, this would give it the functionality of a long range sniper weapon but not overpowered. I would also remove the chainguns perfect accuracy of its first two shots. To balance out the shotgun/super shotgun I would make shotgun ammo way more scarce so having to choose between power and conserving ammo is an actual choice, as it stands in the base game I can just unload a super shotgun blast on lone pistol zombie and not care at all.

For the energy weapons I would bump up the BFGs ammo consumption to 75 or 100 per blast because I never felt the need to use the plasma rifle once I had the BFG as the ammo saved was insignificant especially compared the the time to kill difference between the two. Rocket launcher is perfect as is but it always bothered me that rockets were the only weapon type that only had one weapon, I would add a grenade launcher. A flamethrower would also be nice for damage over time, a nice contrast to the BFG where you have to be looking at the enemy to damage them. For a second flame weapon I would add a three round burst fire flaming stake gun whose bullets would stick into the enemy then explode after a few seconds similar to the needler from halo.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9526138
BFG also is perfectly ammo-efficient on the first shot, dealing exactly 2400 damage for 60 cells (40 per cell). Technically the plasmagun can deal 12, 24, 36, or 48 damage per shot, which averages out to 30 per shot, but you can break it down much more efficiently because one trigger pull is one cell and you don't need to shoot 60 at once. Also if you get lucky you get higher efficiencies, sometimes exceeding the BFG, but not often.
When talking about multiple targets, the BFG loses damage because it splits it damage into groups of 60 (up to 40 projectiles, each dealing Nd60 damage calculated to either kill their target or use up as much of the remaining damage as possible), so anything with health that isn't a multiple of 60 ends up wasting a bit of ammo. Once again, since the PG deals smaller damage per cell good use of it can be more ammo efficient. Definitely can't match the sheer killing speed though.
>math n sheit

If you can manage the CG's absurd fire rate you can reach ammo efficiencies that are second only to the pistol's hypothetical max, but it's really inaccurate and you will waste ammo in some cases so it balances out with the SMG which is highly accurate and fires easily controllable bursts.

>>9526138
The alt-fire of the flare gun is super underrated. It's like the equivalent of being able to shoot a rocket out of the doom pistol for 10 ammo. If you come upon a group of enemies let one of those fly, great way to conserve rocket ammo if you're low and you get a similar outcome. Also I think the cultists have a 100% or close to it stun chance if they get hit, so the tommy gun is extremely good against them due to its high fire rate. I remember the plasma gun being great against the hellhounds, was my go to weapon against that enemy type every time.

Blood is a fantastic FPS once you take the time to understand as much as you can about it (like how jumping and crouching makes hitscanners less accurate, or how you should be bouncing explosives around every suspicious corner, they give you tons of dynamite ammo for a reason). I see alot of people give the game a try, get absolutely wrecked by cultists and give up, but if they just knew a little bit more they would be having a total blast. It's sad.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9528240
That's not too bad of a sprite in itself, but the issue remains of the Chaingunner's appearance as a function of gameplay. His silhouette being too similar to the other zombiemen makes him less easy to identify at a glance or in the dark, and wearing dark brown together with his yet darker complexion, he's going to blend in more in the dark and especially against dark brown textures.

Taking an actual look at the Chaingun Commando, he's noticeably bigger than the other zombies at a glance, carrying a big weapon which is very visibly different at a distance, and his armor is also a darkish red with a harness or strap going across his chest, supporting some sort of ammo pack on his back, which is feeding a belt of linked ammunition to his gun, and that's in addition to his darker skintone and beard.
For his similarities to the other guys, you won't mistake him for the others, and I think that's pretty important considering that this is typically one of the more dangerous enemies in the game, and we're overall sticking to core gameplay.

posts.com:
Update Violent Rumble progs.dat and Trenchbroom FGD are up:
>fixed shotgun last shot issue, and some similar issues with other weapons
>func_rain now has a 'delay' setting that determines its think rate (allows for a nice dripping effect if placed around 1 with a low cnt value)
>monsters can now have various items added to their 'inventory' to drop upon death, webm related*
>new passiveflag for passive until triggered

As usual, yell at me if there are issues.
*Items must both have their 'inventory' value set to 1, and be within the bounding box of a monster. Take into account that bounding boxes shown in editor are (or at least should be) the collision hulls, which may be bigger than the actual size (hitbox) of monsters.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9518542
>>9518605
Decompiling is a pain, and usually, you will need to sort out a lot of things by yourself.
Even if decompilers now can separate code from data (which is helped in consoles starting at PS1 gen because some sort of memory formatting was common) you will likely end up with assembly with variable and functions name meaning nothing.
Well, at least, I tried it for the game boy, and so it was.
I don't see why PS1 would be different (except maybe if they let the debug symbols on the final CD? That's not unheard of, but quite rare).

Anyways, good luck, and enjoy your project!
It you can post your advancements here, that would be really great.

What game do you want to decompile?

>https://tetracorp.github.io/tokimeki-memorial/methods/decompiling-psx-games.html
>https://www.reddit.com/r/REGames/comments/lkbzei/how_to_get_started_decompiling_psx_games/ (I know, Reddit, but, hey, this is sensible for once.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9520325
The Jetsons Invasion of the Planet Pirates comes to mind.
As a licensed game developed by Taito for the SNES, they re-used the game engine and level designs for another licensed game in Japan; Youkai Buster: Ruka no Daibouken.

The game is mostly the same, but the key differences aside from the change in characters and visuals, is a different intro cutscene, the introduction of bonus levels after each action level's boss fight, a whole new final boss, and the inclusion of additional cheat codes whilst the game is paused. The game is however two levels shorter, not all levels were converted from the original game, but some mini-game segments were put in their place.

Whichever version you play though, it is a genuinely good game, nothing amazing, but worth a play.

First, take a crash course in electronics circuits.
Then, build a transiver from 5V to 3.3V.
I think the best way to do it would be to use an ESP32 with WiFi.
Then, code some kind of API (check if extension is present, init, get access point list, connect to one, send a request, receive an answer, etc.
Then, code the software (and if you ant it to be useful, think of it as a project using a lib. Like, don't do some URL check or whatever in the game code.)
Lastly, enjoy!
I would start super simple with a game that just check if the extension is plugged.
An other on that does that and list the networks and their strength.
Lastly, one that goes and fetch a text file somewhere on the internet.

As for the hardware, I don't know what buses the NES have exposed. Maybe the same as cartridges? If so, you are midly fucked. You expansion may present as a RAM page, where you write at some addresses, and it gives you answers at other addresses?

>>9531863
Just fantasizing at the moment, although I wanted to know on a technical level that it could be done, which it can be by the sounds of it. Software-level stuff isn't a barrier for me since I've done plenty of ASM in the past. The motivation was more about adding network features to existing games. One crazy idea that has been in my head for the past few weeks was a SMB3 NES/SNES rom hack I wanted to call "Doomship Raider", where you could take over enemy airships by playing them, crudely build your own, fly to locations, and seize other players' ships by invading them with your own. No idea how the gameplay of that would pan out, or if it would be any fun at all, but I recognize that without a bit of planning first, the ideas of the hack and the propositions of doing the network stuff in the first place would fall flat. It's already enough that I'm writing a brand new level editor for SMB3, so it really is just a time-investing interest that could crop up if I've got time I don't want to waste on something else.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9532426
>Are there any NES games that make use of the "illegal opcodes" I hear exist in the 6502?
"Games using unofficial opcodes

The use of unofficial opcodes is rare in NES games. It appears to occur mostly in late or unlicensed titles:

Beauty and the Beast (E) (1994) uses $80 (a 2-byte NOP).[2]
Disney's Aladdin (E) (December 1994) uses $07 (SLO). This is Virgin's port of the Game Boy game, itself a port of the Genesis game, not any of the pirate originals.
Dynowarz: Destruction of Spondylus (April 1990) uses 1-byte NOPs $DA and $FA on the first level when your dino throws his fist.
F-117A Stealth Fighter uses $89 (a 2-byte NOP).
Gaau Hok Gwong Cheung (Ch) uses $8B (XAA immediate) as a 2-byte NOP. The game malfunctions after selecting Left from the main menu if that instruction is not emulated.
Infiltrator uses $89 (a 2-byte NOP).
Puzznic (all regions) (US release November 1990) uses $89 (a 2-byte NOP).
Super Cars (U) (February 1991) uses $B3 (LAX).

Homebrew games

The MUSE music engine, used in Driar and STREEMERZ: Super Strength Emergency Squad Zeta, uses $8F (SAX), $B3 (LAX), and $CB (AXS).[3]
Attribute Zone uses $0B (ANC), $2F (RLA), $4B (ALR), $A7 (LAX), $B3 (LAX), $CB (AXS), $D3 (DCP) and $DB (DCP).
The port of Zork to the Famicom uses a few unofficial opcodes."
From: https://www.nesdev.org/wiki/CPU_unofficial_opcodes

The real boom happened with the Wii's Virtual Console, showing every publisher you could sell literally million of copies of NES games they all thought were just dead weight, followed by games like Mega Man 9 showing every publisher you could sell literally million of copies of new NES-like games with small budgets.

This makes the collectorfags seethe, but it's digitalizion of the media that made "retro gaming" what it is. Many of the -I only play games from the plastic I buy- "purists" wouldn't even be here had digital retro gaming not made things trendy.

Yeah, "people never stopped playing" old games, and yes, re-release collections of older games were already a thing, but they were marginal. It wasn't a real market until the Wii came around.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9524408
Unfortunately, it's not easily obtainable knowledge, you should know C, you should understand how the compilator processes your code and you should understand the assembly language of a target platform(MIPS in the case of PSX). Tools allow you to decompile an executable file to asm functions with generic names, even convert them to c. But it's not like load exe to Ghidra and getting a working code.

In rare cases, devs forgot the symbol file on a disk so you can obtain names for functions and variables but usually, they don't. So you need to guess names for thousands of functions and variables.

Reverse engineering is a hobby for a high skilled and autistic programmers.

Fair enough, but the way some stuff is being shown in Retrotech videos is misleading at best. I'm not saying he's doing it in bad faith, it's just that the way it's sold can induce unecessary panic in people that don't know better. And if they decide to then recap a set based on that, they'll often end up creating a problem rather than fixing one.

I think he has a lot of very useful practical knowledge about fixing CRTs, but he should know when he's out of his depth on technical matters and just flat out tell people: "look, I'm not exactly sure about this but this is what I think is going on" or something along those lines. He clearly lacks knowledge about some of the details of how the electronic circuitry actually works. There's no shame in that, just be honest.

>>9516704
You can clean mold off VHS tapes. Open top case of VCR. Fast forward the tape. As its running, lightly press Qtip dipped in rubbing alcohol against the capstan so the tape runs across it. Cleans all the mold off. I've done it several times and saved some rare tapes this way.

posts.com:
- CRTs are no longer produced because they have inferior picture quality versus LCDs
- CRTs emit dangerous levels of X-rays or other forms of radiation
- CRTs always have easily-visible flicker
- CRTs always cause eyestrain
- CRTs always make a high-pitched squealing noise
- CRTs contain lethal amounts of electricity, even when unplugged
- CRTs need calibration more than two to three times a year
- Overall CRT black levels are not superior to LCDs because ambient light ruins CRT black levels
- Analog CRTs have more processing time than digital LCDs due to poor RAMDAC performance
- Afterimages caused by phosphor decay are extremely annoying and are a significant downside of CRTs
- Sending an improper mode (resolution or refresh rate) to a CRT can cause permanent damage
- CRTs cannot have touchscreens
- 4:3 is so bad that nobody should use a non-widescreen CRT
- The Sony GDM-FW900 is the only CRT worth owning
- Curved CRTs have objectively inferior picture quality versus flat CRTs with otherwise equal specifications
- CRTs should not be used because they are heavier and deeper than LCDs
- CRTs have severe reflections because they do not have matte coats
- CRTs can be permanently damaged by nearby magnets
- You will not have sex in 2023
- Analog signals limit a CRT's resolutions and refresh rates and negatively effect picture quality
- Heavy metals are used in CRT glass to reduce radiation

Games should be categorized based on the types of technology used, not arbitrary release dates. Look at the way architecture is categorized for example (Classical, Mid-century modern, Postmodern, Neomodern, New Classical, Contemporary, etc…). Mid century modern will never become classical. Similarly, Jazz music will never become classical. Its dumb to call an 8 bit hand held a later gen just because it came out later. The gamegear is literally just a master system. The Wii is literally just an overclocked gamecube and has a weaker CPU & GPU than the Xbox. Using this logic, here's the REAL gaming eras:

Pre-Retro Era:
Gen 1 - Literally just Pong
Gen 2 - Atari 26/52/78, Vectrex, shitboxes nobody cares about

[Insert Gaming Crash Here]

Retro Era AKA The Golden Age:
Gen 3 (8 Bit) - NES, Gameboy, Gameboy Color, Master System, Game Gear, PC 88, MSX, ZX Spectrum, Pico-8, TIC-80
Gen 4 (16 bit) - SNES, GBA, Genesis, PC98, TG16, Amiga, Neo Geo
Gen 4.5 - Sega 32X, 3DO, PC-FX
Gen 5 (32 bit 2D + Low Poly 3D) - PS1, Saturn, N64, DS
Gen 5.5 - Dreamcast, PSP, 3DS
Gen 6 (Mid Poly) - PS2, Gamecube, Wii

[Insert Globohomo Here]

Modern Era (HD widescreen, Microtransactions, Day 1 patches, hyper realism, Casualization, homogenized controllers, homogenized architecture, mocap, facescan, Californian management, etc...):
Gen 6.5 (High Poly, 480p-ish) - Xbox, Vita
Gen 7 (Mainly 720p) - 360, PS3, Wii U,
Gen 7.5 - Switch
Gen 8 (Gen 7 + Stable 1080p) - PS4, Xbone
Gen 8.5 (Gen 7 + 4K) - PS4 Pro, Xbone X
Gen 9 (Gen 7 + 4K + RTX) - PS5, Xbox SX

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9527523
The first one or the second one? I think the first one is harder. Always keep him at the edge of your screen so he can't reach you with the fire even if he suddenly decides to move towards you, and double jump to hit him twice every time. If he's about to shot the laser it's better to wait, if he's almost off screen chances are he'll shoot the laser straight ahead and miss you, but sometimes it doesn't work so you're better off not jumping until he's done. Oh and you better have the golden armour equipped because otherwise the bracelet has pathetic range and it's weaker too. The green boss is much easier, he only shoots fire at his feet so that should never hit you, except when he gets to the edge of the platform, in that case just back away and wait. The superlaser is also easy to avoid, just be careful when he stops shooting fire and might shoot the laser and duck.

If they fix up the old girl so it runs better, I would be willing to accept that tradeoff (even if slightly begrudgingly), the gory violence and disgusting monsters are the primary draws of Splatterhouse after all. Plus, it would presumably still come with the classic games, so it'd have a value on that alone.

For a real wildcard, "Probably Not" tier possibility, an all new 2D sidescroller styling itself after the classics would work. There's a kind of precedent in that, because there's been a few classic IPs which have gotten that treatment, such as Kunio Kun and TMNT, the latter apparently is pretty good, while the former was supposedly more lukewarm and felt like someone trying to do their own thing with a preexisting IP.

>>9527356
>don't think I've ever seen a source for that but I've read it in other places. I don't know where the rumor comes from or if it's true.
Right, but it's definitely an idea that's been going around online, true or not. It's a small form of vindication for me at any rate, even finding out that it's definitely untrue would be interesting enough for me.

With some extensive Googling and searching, I found a couple of references to it on TVTropes (unsourced, and who knows when they were added), a brief thread about it on R*ddit from earlier this year, and then some scant few mentions of it in the archives of /vr/ and /v/ dating back the past decade or so.
If it's actually true, potentially the one source is actually in Japanese and it's something that's only been wandering around the western world by word of mouth, and either it was never translated, or the translation of it fell off the web at some point.

What we have to back it is 1, that the claim of the idea has been passed around for a long time (never challenged and never sourced), but of slightly stronger substance, 2, there's some interviews with the devs where they do actually mention that Namco made them change a number of things about the game to tone it down, such as making the zombies less realistic and human looking, making the blood green, etc.
There's no mention about the concept of the player character, but that wouldn't have to mean that it wasn't something which changed during development, regardless of it was something changed in the last minute as often told of, or if it was something which was proposed but nixed early on. The player initially being proposed as an evil killer looking to murder a poor girl, then being changed into a hero trying to save his girl would be going from a darker to a lighter tone, and it would make the fact that the player looks like a famous slasher horror killer less inexplicable.

I played a part of KH1 as a kid and played through the whole game a couple weeks ago. I had a good enough time, though I found it pretty easy once you got Second Chance. Then I played KH2 which I had never played. I dropped 2. I think a little bit of the jank worked for the first game, prevented you from being too much of a god and gave you reason to use your other abilities. I've seen people insist 2 isn't just mash X to win and your magic is good, but it felt like they streamlined melee attacks but not magic so you either mash X and do a ton of damage or you entirely break your flow to cast a couple spells that do next to nothing. It didn't help that it felt like 2 was dripfeeding you spells, too. I ended up dropping 2 because the combat just wasn't very interesting to me and the amount of cutscenes was just frustrating with how often it took control away from you. And that Roxas intro was so dull.

Overall, I think KH1 was the better game, even though it had its annoyances; I found that I probably didn't finish the game as a retarded child because I kept thinking "where the fuck do I go" and it'd be things like climbable vines that didn't stand out well enough against a tree and things like that.

Yeah, when they’re done well.

Inserting cartoon characters into an already well-established and popular aesthetic (in this case basketball/hip hop) works because it doesn’t break the layer of irony that comes with it. In the case of those Looney Tunes, it’s “cool” because it’s kind of funny.

Whereas with this shit >>9525010, it’s Mickey Mouse trying WAY too hard to look cute in an edgy, almost emo sort of way. posts.com:
KH1 has got the most perfect pacing when it comes to gameplay progression and powercreep

Sora starts with very simple movement and his attacks are very simple, by the end once you face off the extra bosses you really feel like you have grown as a character specially if you craft all end game weapons for all 3, many games fail at recreating this feel and it's very rewarding

Also I do agree with posts above, end game Sora in KH1 feels very balanced compared to end game Sora in KH2

Having said that though I think I like KH2 for completely different reasons, it being a pseudo Devil May Cry with JRPG elements being one of them, also KH2 is more "anime" than KH1 because of all the 1v1 fights and all the cool shit Nomura included in many of the bosses and general gameplay

Really wished the gameplay would have remained good because Square had something great going on before they killed the franchise with BBS (I also like this entry though but modern KH is nothing like what KH1 and KH2 used to be)

My favorite thing about this game was how it starts you off on this ethereal comfy island with all your friends (who are kid versions of characters from final fantasy games you already played) and then it transports you to fucking Disney animated universe with movies you already watched. It was so weird and interesting, and I really like how they did the 2D Disney cartoons in 3D without losing much in translation.
Embarrassing to admit to liking something so autistic but holy shit this was a drug to a child in 2002.
It lives and dies by its incredible opening, that tropical island as your door to a new universe was expertly done.

It's a fairly accessible field to anyone wanting to make a game about such a topic and it comes with a ready-made audience and so on. It's basically normal to such an extent you wouldn't even think twice about it.
But in Japan their SDF is not something any game I can think of glorifies or even uses in a current day setting. It's simply not done. So if you're a japanese military gear autist, historically, IMHO, your autism would have to be sated in some setting removed from the current day SDF. So they started inventing many different outlets for this. Gundam, Front Mission, Macross, etc...Even Ace Combat has thematically randomized factions. But the point is that THAT's how japanese military autists get their kick. They can argue about the gear, logistics, tactics, strategy, etc... in these fictional settings and so on.. it's definitely a thing. And yeah if SDF or some near-current day version of it every comes into play it's always done with some "take" on it rather than a straightforward gung-ho way military is in the west.
I think it's just a profound difference that possibly played a significant part in the mecha genre. It's just an outlet for those gear porn urges.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The Oracle games are some of the worst the series has produced and I don't understand why anyone considers these better than Link's Awakening. Seasons is the better of the two, but still bland. Ages has a bunch of tedious bullshit that wastes your time, switching eras takes way too long and involves a lot of trial and error since warping to a non-walkable space means you have to warp back and then reposition yourself. Doing this multiple times during every trek across the overworld gets annoying quick since the harp song+warp cutscene can't be skipped. Both have the ring system where you find mystery rings which are appraised at a shop, but they're all so useless you'll forget it's even part of the game. The linked game concept was neat, but most of the items you can get aren't worth the hassle (and the ones that are aren't available for most of the game). The dungeons have rooms larger than the screen, unlike LA, but they do nothing with the extra space. Seasons has a few neat nods to Zelda 1, some of the dungeon layouts and bosses are directly inspired by that game. The story isn't anything special, Link gets sent by the Triforce to two different kingdoms where the Twinrova witches are trying to manipulate the local villains into kidnapping the sages of (game title) so they can light some magic flames to bring back Ganon. Soundtracks are completely forgettable. Graphics are a gross hodgepodge of recolored Link's Awakening assets and hastily made tiles that don't match at all. Special shoutout to the Ages Goron simon says dance mini-game that requires you to match a tempo perfectly on beat with zero sound cues.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9521549

They're zoomer retards, it's that simple, don't try to reason with them.

They think they are "recreating" the "effect" of a CRT screen, but that's not what they are doing, and unless they have a HDR 8K monitor that's barely even possible. Let alone on the garbage 10 year old 1080P panel they probably use them on.

The annoying thing is, filters are not a meme; but the real function is to simply break the image up. That's what a REAL CRT does. It's a form of natural anti-aliasing, it's an optical illusion that tricks your eye into thinking the pixels blend together. If people were making filters that did this without trying to replicate a CRT we would probably have vastly superior filters.

Personally I just use a 50% opaque scanline filter, and increase brightness to compensate, making sure the line integer matches the internal rendering resolution. When I play from sofa distance I can't see the lines, it just looks like a smooth image instead. It's not as perfect as a real CRT but it's better than the eye-strain inducing garbage of "CRT filters".

posts.com:
2 is impressive for how much they were able to do with a snes rpg but it’s quite rough around the edges, even compared to other games of that time. The upside is you can get right into the action pretty quickly. If you play it, be sure to use the fan retranslation and maybe the hack that lowers the encounter rate.
3 is great, definitely the best if you stick with it but it takes a very long time for the game to pick up. The first 10-15 hours are basically just a prologue.

>>9523968
The hardware is deigned like a 2D system what with it's dedicated sprite and background layers, similar to a SNES or a Genesis except more powerfil. Sprites can be arbitrarily scaled, skewed, distorted on all 4 points, allowing devs to do real fake 3D on the Saturn. The background layer is kind of like the SNES, mode 7 effects et-al.

The problem is that due to the sprite nature of the Saturn, you can't really do any advanced 3D effects like reflection mapping due to no real UV mapping support or advanced blending effects.

>>9523983
The PS1 was designed like a real (albeit limited) 3D system from the start with it's hardware accelerated transformation via it's GTE and support for other 3D rendering features.

They're all 2D systems pretending to be 3D.

>>9523960
The designers were simply bad at predicting how 3D console games would shake out.
Composited background layers might make sense when you're making arcade games with a fixed or simplistic perspective but they suck ass for games with a free perspective. Same with forward mapped polygons, which are terrible when polygons can be arbitrarily close to the camera or god forbid near the edges of the viewport.
They also underestimated how many polygons the next gen would be capable of, resulting in the awkward extra SH-2 and underutilized SCU DSP.

>>9524117
PS1 and Saturn were both designed to do 3D in theory. The Saturn's trademark titles are Virtua Fighter and Virtua Racing, which are 3D games. But the issue is that 3D games and technology wasn't fully understood by most developers or the manufacturers. The PS1 and Staturn have much more rudimentary 3D capabilities just by the virtue of being older and because it was harder for devs to figure out or confidently enter. N64 has a big advantage by being created 2 years later with Mario 64 in mind. N64 also had the advantage of being made by much more talented computer engineers from the US who understood 3D better as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Saturn has very weird architecture. Very few devs ended up taking fully advantage of both VDPs, and even then they couldn't do much with some actual limitations like the infamous transparency issue.
at then end, it doesn't matter because the game library is fantastic (especially if you know Japanese, to be fair), and 2D more than make up for 3D limitations.
Playstation is a fantastically-designed system which pushed 3D gaming into an affordable space. By the way, teexture warping is pure soul, and weirdly ended up giving a more "organic" look compared to the clean 3D of powerful PC graphics cards. Real issue was the lack of RAM, especially since it's was the only system without RAM carts expansions. Big 2D arcade ports were terrible because of this.
N64 is the real stinker of the gen. Great polygon pushing capabilities and that's it. Horrendous viewing distance with fog everywhere to hide it, pathetic texture cache, no dedicated sound chip,... It doesn't help that devs prioritized resolution and polygon-count over framerate. And let's not talk about the 2D games offering (since there's barely anything to talk about).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9524623
The N64's 3D was less rudimentary than the Playstation's, but the Playstation's was also less rudimentary than the Saturn's. The "Saturn is 2D pretending to be 3D" line is an annoying oversimplification but forward mapped polygons which don't support UV coordinates, clipping, or environment mapping are certainly more primitive.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9524506
Tomb Raider isn't held back by VDP1's fill rate. You can go in and modify the draw commands to draw wireframes instead, which significantly reduces the amount of pixels VDP1 needs to draw and how much fill rate is needed. If you do this however you'll notice the game still chugs and slows down in the exact same spots to the exact same levels of performance. This indicates that VDP1 fillrate is NOT what's causing the performance issues. This means it could either be a CPU bottle neck, memory bottlenecks, etc. Odds are the game just didn't get the final bits of optimization the PS1 port got due to the Saturn port being rushed out sooner.

The other thing to keep in mind is that Sony had their performance analyzer that could tell devs exactly where the bottleneck was in their code and how to fix it. Neither Sega nor Nintendo had anything like that. So that helped developers produce faster code.

So while VDP1's fill rate is lower than the PS1's GPU, it's not the massive performance gap many think it is. Most of these games aren't doing anything that should be getting close to that limit. To hit that limit you need to be doing something really dumb like rendering the entire frame with transparent polygons or not having any code to sort and eliminate non visible polygons.

>>9524798
This is a myth. The PS1 was sold at a similar loss to the Saturn when it launched in 1994 in Japan. This has been revealed by recent interviews from employees involved in both companies. PS1 cost about 50,000 Yen per unit to produce, Saturn cost about 54,800 Yen. Yes Saturn is more, but it's not $100 more. Both systems were sold at a $100 loss as well. The biggest cost issue in both systems wasn't the number of chips, it was the RAM. RAM prices were stupid high during this time and fell dramatically in the next 3 years. What was over $200 worth of RAM in both systems dropped to under $5 worth of RAM in the span of 2-3 years.

People love to point to $399 vs $299 but forget to look at the difference in launch dates. By the time the PS1 launched at $299 Sega had already dropped the Saturn to $349 due to the new VA1 revision and falling RAM prices with it still coming with a game. If you bought a game with your PS1 at launch, you'd be paying the same amount. 2-3 weeks after the PS1 launched Sega released a Saturn that didn't come with a game for $299. By late Spring of 1996 both systems dropped to $199 due to RAM prices continuing to fall dramatically, and in Sega's case more cost reductions with the Model 2 Saturn.

The price wasn't the issue, it was the horrible launch line up in the US.

The Saturn's VDP2 was effectively an entirely separate GPU with dedicated VRAM so a game could offload environments to it and not have to compete with other things for resources in the way the PS1 does.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9525101
> it means UP TO 6x, meaning in the worst case scenario, meaning all effects on + transparency, vs no effects on and no transparency.

I literally said that figure applied to rendering transparencies. Gouraud Shading doesn't really have much of a performance hit on VDP1. If you want to know how that figure is actually determined it basically boils down to this.

- A non textured pixel takes about 1 clock cycle to draw.
- A textured pixel takes about 2 cycles to draw.
- A textured and gouraud shaded pixel still takes about 2 cycles to draw.
- A half transparent pixel takes about 6 cycles to draw.

So compared to untextured pixels it's 6 times longer to draw, compared to textured it's 3 times longer to draw. So this is where your up to 6 times longer comes from. So with those values we can say that the max theoretical fillrate of VDP1 is 26-28 Million pixels per second depending on what resolution mode the Saturn is in and if you're drawing all untextured pixels. This is probably how the theoretical value listed earlier was determined. For Textured and Gouraud shaded pixels it's about 13-14 Million pixels per second. For half transparent pixels, it's about 4-5 Million pixels per second.

That's still a pretty significance performance hit for half transparencies. Throw in that they don't work correctly all the time and it's easy to see why most devs went with meshes.

That all said, if you're not doing half transparencies VDP1's fillrate is still more than enough for most games. At 320x240 resolution at 30fps you have enough fillrate to draw the entire frame buffer about 6 times per frame. So if you're sorting and culling polygons properly and not trying to draw everything as half transparent, you really shouldn't be hitting the fillrate limit.

>>9525162
iirc vdp1 requires 1 cycle to prepare a pixel and 1 to write, so nontextured pixel is 2 cycles and textured is 3. half transparency is 6. gouraud shading only increases the per-polygon setup time.

>we can say that the max theoretical fillrate of VDP1 is 26-28 Million pixels per second
26/28 mpixels assumes perfect access of memory on every cycle, not possible because the vdp1 uses sdram, and you have to deal with page miss penalties.

The real peak fillrate is ~24 mpixels peak. early docs flat out state this number. there's at least one homebrew app that measures this same speed on the sh2 side which also uses sdram.

one of the docs gives an actual figure you can use for approximating both texture drawing time, vdp1 per-polygon setup, and page miss penalties. i don't remember the exact values but you could only hit two digit practical fillrates if you did zero effects. with textures, you can barely fill a 320x224 framebuffer twice before you drop out from 60fps.

>>9523968
It's GPU was essentially a 2D GPU, the very way textures and their polygons worked was an extension of just applying transform effects to sprites. This is why they used quads instead of triangles, since a sprite is a flat image that has 4 corners. They essentially hacked up 2D GPU techniques with enough transform effects to make it kinda sorta work like a 3D GPU. The quads was a major reason why the Saturn could not do transparency effects except for sprites.

>>9523983
>>9523993
Bull. While the PS1 lacked a Z-buffer, it's GPU actually rendered in a 3D plane and was made for realtime 3D, it didn't hack up sprites to the point that you were using them in place of textures because you could apply enough transform effects to them to make them kinda sorta work as 3D polygons.

Yes, everything rasterizes the final image onto a 2D screen, that does not mean "every system is 2D", it's rasterizing a 3D image to a 2D screen.

The Saturn needed some more time to cook, not less.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9528636
A CD can store higher quality textures compared to what you could fit onto a cartridge but that's more or less it when it comes to in-game graphics. A CD won't help you push more polygons or anything and you're still limited primarily by the system's RAM. The N64's unified RAM architecture is probably what hurt it the most. It was obviously a cost cutting measure but back then you really needed dedicated VRAM.

Instead of holding several frames of animation for hitsparks, SFA3 squashes and stretches a single frame as a means of reducing the number of tiles it needs to keep in memory. It's a small but very practical way of lowering VRAM use.

Parallax scrolling in SFA3 backgrounds are also rendered using polys on Playstation since raster effects aren't doable.

The game itself is not really that slow, especially when you know what you're doing. If you mean slowdown, yeah it is pretty bad (just like the Metal Slug games), but you can remove it through emulation and the game is massively improved.

The rank system is kinda fucked though; the game is actually easier if you don't pick up all the powerups. You need to make the decision between rushing past sections or going slow and thorough. When you learn the game, you can do sections very quickly and pointblanking shreds bosses.

Just like with the Slug games, turbo + removing slowdown makes the game so much better. With turbo you can also pointblank the last boss and it dies way faster (he also has less health with lower rank from not picking up as many powerups). I'm not sure what other problems you are having with the last level, it's just all about routing and figuring out how best to approach each section consistently (like any good shmup/run-n-gun)

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9526672
It was always a tech demo
VF1: just its existence was revolutionary, from the system to the models. Hair and cloth physics, even animated faces.
VF2: texture-mapping
VF3: eye-tracking, more dynamic faces, hair and cloth physics expanded upon, uneven stages and dodge button
VF4: first 3DFG with customization and an online service (arcade only), introduced side-stepping, breakable walls, one stage had a snowy floor and another a watery floor
VF5: Ultimate was done in the Dragon engine, but that's all I remember

The framerate was one of the big improvements that Virtua Fighter 2 made over Virtua Fighter 1. The first game still looked incredible for a 1993 release, but it is still the slowest playing of the Virtua Fighter series. Kinda like how Street Fighter 1 ran at a low framerate. All of the home ports of Virtua Fighter 1 are locked down to 30fps. The 32x game retains 30fps for the majority of the game, but has some slowdown during the win/ lose cutscenes. One of the big enhancements that the model 2 arcade board made was the 60 (57fps) framerate. Every Model 2 arcade game targeted 57fps. Though the Saturn and many of the home ports (Excluding the Genesis port) run at a slightly higher framerate than the arcade game at a real 60fps.

>>complains when character design is grounded

That is the weird thing about Virtua fighter. The characters are tempered (somewhat), but there are still these game like elements. Like Sarah being the blonde brainwashed assassin trope. battle Arena did kind of the same thing with Sonya. Nina is the blonde brainwashed assassin type in Tekken. Why was that a thing in 3D fighters? Akira kinda being the series Ryu, though even more boring. Jackie looks like a Ken clone, but is more like Sarah. Jeffrey is oddly more original characters. Pai is teen idol trope. Lau Chan is/ was an antagonist to Akira. Maru is mysterious ninja trope. Shun Di = drunken old man (best character), Taka =- we added a Sumo wrestler. yeah, the characters are the most basic versions of tropes. DOA goes in the complete opposite, but still features all the same tropes. It's hard to fault anyone that says they are kinda dull. But oddly done that way by design. the characters in the games are best defied by their move sets/ fighting styles. They do try to go for some authentic fighting moves, for each character.

In most video games for the Olympics, football/soccer, and team sports in general, were usually left out, with the main exception I can think of being... the Mario & Sonic franchise. 2020 was probably the best year in that regard, both Mario & Sonic at Tokyo 2020 and the official Tokyo 2020 video game feature football/soccer, and both have better turfs and lighting than eFootball still, which is sort of funny.

When it comes to video games that are 100% made with Olympic football/soccer in mind I can only think of Olympic Soccer 1996 and Winning Eleven 2000, with the latter actually being incredible to me.

I wish that we'd get these stand alone adaptations again, or maybe that the official Paris 2024 video game actually gives the sport more care and adds the official players and nations, anything but a bare bones DLC for EA Sports FC or eFootball that'll just be lost in time eventually, I want to be able to go back to a tournament like I can go back to any FIFA World Cup before 2018, when it became a DLC.

I've never managed to get into FIFA either, I'll admit that a lot of that was due to me being way too biased towards Winning Eleven, I missed out on what most consider the golden age of FIFA (FIFA 08 - FIFA16) because of that and I regret it, anyways when FIFA19 came bundled in with my PS4 I gave it a fair shot and... despised it with every fiber of my being, and went back to what I knew best, anything by Konami. I've been giving FIFA more changes recently, especially on Genesis and PS1, but they're never my cup of tea, either they're just not fun to play, downright frustrate me (FIFA19 I'm looking at you) or are just so inferior to what Konami had to offer at around the same time, sometimes even inferior to other developers, since back then it wasn't a duopoly. I'll never get how FIFA became so dominant, though that might be because I missed out on the installments that made it get so big, but all of my experiences were subpar, EA's almost never done football any justice.

>FPS
Unreal Tournament '99, I didn't like FPS games way back then, but it's good ol' UT that made me enjoy the genre. And turned me into an Unreal fanboy.
>VS Fighting
Advanced V.G. 2. This one is thanks to fellow /vr/os, as many anons were talking about the V.G. series and characters in various threads so I decided to give it a shot. The first game is kinda meh SF2 clone, but the second one is very fun, despite still being largely derivative of other games in the genre. And Yuka is the best girl.. I'm gonna try Asuka 120% games next.
>jRPG
Chrono Trigger, along with RPG Maker game called The Way. Never liked most of RPGs, regardless if these are turn-based or action, Japanese or Western, since I used to see them as grindfests for the most part (which is mostly true). CT however has good enough balancing that allows to breeze through the game without grinding at all, plus familiar Toriyama character design (watched Dragon Ball a lot as a kid) and time travelling - that had me sold. And The Way has a ridiculously good story that puts CT and other 16-bit RPGs to shame, though it suffers in terms of gameplay mechanics, still a very enjoyable experience.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9528931
The special moves are less of the problem than the normals. Smash only has one normal button, so it's much easier to understand what each punch in your kit is for. If the enemy is behind you, you do a backward attack. If the enemy is below you, you down a downward aerial attack. While in fighting games, stuff like the crouching medium kick will only have an extremely circumstantial use.

One of Smash's biggest advantages is that the character's normal kits are usually similar enough that you can tell what your opponent's going to do just from their positioning. I think the more recent games in the series have ruined that somewhat, by introducing characters who have deceptively large range on specific attacks that will blindside you if aren't familiar with the character (or just forgot).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9526568
Not exactly retro, but Etrian Odyssey got me to go back and play classic dungeon crawlers like Wizardry. It was mostly in its way of looking at your party as actual characters with different motivations for dungeon delving, different backgrounds, personalities, and narrating the story of their adventure from their eyes instead of seeing the whole thing as cold, hard numbers in a video game. I started treating the genre as a tabletop game after that and found it much easier to get into when I could think of a random encounter not just being an ogre one shoting my thief but instead a sequence where the group stumbled upon a sleeping giant and woke him up, the resulting scramble to escape seeing Arn the Scoundrel's charm and wits failing him as a smack from a tree trunk being used as an improvised club sends him sailing across the dungeon while the rest of the party attempts to regroup and protect their companion.

Prior to that, I had always treated games I've played as video games first and foremost, with story and exposition relegated specifically to cutscenes and such. After playing EO, I started to give meaning to the happenings in the gameplay itself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9526568
I can't say that I "disliked" them, but there were some genres that I didn't care for until I played a game from them that I particularly liked.

RTS: Total Annihilation: Kingdoms - The first RTS game that I cared about from start to finish. It had a compelling storyline, forced you to play all of the sides (which also forced you to "git gud" at all sorts of strategies and tactics) and didn't bog you down in the "I need nine resources and four buildings and these units to produce X" grind. Really unfortunate that the game became the knee-jerk excuse for why Cavedog 'failed.'

ARPGs - Titan Quest. I had played Diablo 1/2 and I was like "eh. That's nice. Not an FPS." Titan Quest, though, was the first ARPG that I wanted to play from start to finish. Again, I think it was the setting and storyline (as weak as it was in relation to other genres) that sold me on it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Adventures of Batman and Robin on the SNES was my favorite as a kid. I loved the show so much and this game had such perfectly faithful presentation that it felt like playing the show itself. Each stage began with a title card in the same style as the ones in the show, followed by a cutscene and dialogue with Alfred setting up a mission. Pretty much every major villain was in the game and there were bits of dialogue with them too. You had a bunch of gadgets to use and there was some variety to the stages too so it actually felt like playing as Batman and not like a generic beat-em-up or run-and-gun with a coat of paint like a lot of superhero games at the time were. Pretty much a perfect adaptation as far as I'm concerned, the only flaw was being single player only.

>>9527536
I was fond of Death & Return as a kid for a similar reason as above, it was a direct and faithful adaptation of a storyline from the comics. They even reproduced panels from the comic as cutscenes which was really neat to see. But unfortunately it's really just a repetitive beat-em-up underneath it all.

I love it and it's short lenght makes me replay it often, I feel that the criticism it gets can be fair, but often it can go a little beyond what it deserves, it's not that bad, it plays fine and it's fun.

Some SFC-exclusive series

The Great Battle series: Six games of varying action-platform styles of play (overhead, beat-em-up, run 'n gun, etc) with a cast made of of various Bandai/Banpresto owned franchises like Gundam, Ultraman, Kamen Rider, etc. The fourth game plays a lot like Megaman X with mech battles and the fifth one is basically Wild Guns-style gameplay mixed with a platformer, the best ones.

Go Go Ackman: Comedic action-platformers created by Akira Toriyama.

Parodius: Konami's parody shmup series, the third one, Chatting Parodius, has the most recorded vocal audio I've ever heard in a SNES/SFC game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9525483
>Can someone explain to me why source code matters
If you have the source code, the nuts and bolts of how a video game is made, you can potentially create really good modding or editing tools to add on to the game. You can already do with games that don't have publicly available source codes, but with the meat and potatoes of it the possibilities are an order of magnitude greater, including the end-user possibly creating their own game with that code. This has already happened with things like Doom's source code, Quake's source code, etc. On the flipside, sometimes source codes get released (legally or otherwise) and nothing really happens because people don't care enough.
>Why don't we already have it?
Developer, software, and publisher rights. Let's say Ed Boon was the sole owner of the source code of MKII. If it was never released, it's because he didn't want it released. But let's say Ed Boon doesn't own it and the parent company to Netherealm Studios owns the MKII source code. If Ed Boon WANTED the MKII source code out there, he'd have to go through corporate, who could just say no since he doesn't own it. If he did it anyway, he could get sued into the ground.
>Have the games not been downloaded and emulated. Are we not able to see the code then, or hack it? Why not?
All source code is converted into machine code so the computer can read it. That means only the truly adept can reverse engineer a video game, and this has happened more than once.

You didn't ask but I feel like video game studios/publishers should just release source codes far more often than they do. Croteam, the developers of Serious Sam, released the source code for Serious Sam 1's engine for free. But that was in 2017 or so, so literally who the fuck cared anymore besides serious Serious Sam fanboys? Unity, Unreal, Godot, etc. have all taken off. If Croteam had released SE1 back in 2003 after The Secound Encounter came out the FPS landscape might have been different.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9525483
The ROM image contains "low level" machine code that is run directly on the CPU. Programmers write in a highly level code, like C (higher level languages you may have heard of are C#, JavaScript, Python, Java, etc., but old school arcade games never used these as they needed to be more optimised for performance) school, which goes through a "compilation" process to turn it into machine code. The code written by the programmer is the source code, and you can't directly extract this from the compiled machine code. Writing in Assembly is as close to machine code as you can get, but even then, there are comments in the file and descriptive names for variables that are lost in the compilation process. Decompilation projects manually review all the compiled code and try to recreate what they think the source code would have looked like before it was compiled. This can be verified, to a degree, by compiling the manually decompiled code and seeing if it matches the ROM, but all the identifier names and any programmer comments cannot be derived from the ROM image.

The way source code functions as a part of the final end product of a finished game, is that all of the human-readable code has been converted into machine language. Operating instructions for the system to perform mathematical instructions and moving memory around. This is the reason why we can't just "crack" the source code out of a game. The Mario 64 decomp devs actually went through every single instruction and deduced their purposes on a larger scale in a ridiculously difficult and drawn out process using emulators and debuggers.

It is NOT easy. Pic is "source" code. You cannot run this through a converter and spit out legible code.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's a very good game, with extremely strange mechanics. The problem is that the in-game tutorials are shit, and the mechanics are at times contradictory and counter-intuitive. But it's worth playing for the story, music, and graphics.

Weapons have type, affinities, and class. Learn what these mean from an online guide. Be aware that it'll be impossible to match them up perfectly, and (even if you could) it would be tedious to swap your weapon for every enemy. FYI, type has an outsized role in the damage calculation, affinity is medium, and class is the least. So just focus on type and ignore the others, but you may switch for affinities very rarely if it's a big encounter and you have a great weapon for it.

Read how crafting works online. You MUST craft and you MUST know how combinations work. Drops in chests are shit.

There's an optional dungeon. Get to the end of the first floor and use the item they give you for crafting. It's phenomenal against the final boss.

If you get good stat bonus rolls, stay current with competent crafting, and use the correct type, you'll become OP and finish most end-game boss fights in just a few rounds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9522394

You don't need a guide.
The weapon crafting in this game is similar to demon fusion in SMT games.
The game throws a lot of weapons at you through drops/chests and it's up to you to fuse them into better ones.
You can simply go to a blacksmith's shop and try combining random ones to see what you get.
Some combinations give you a similar weapon, some the same but augmented, some a weapon of a higher tier and some a completely different "type". You can easily experiment with all this on your own and figure it out on the go.

The idea is to upgrade your weapons but keep an eye on the stats so certain ones keep improving etc...

It's not monotonous or difficult, if you play in exact the "optimized" way. That is, have 3 weapons (one for each type), and focus only on type. Switch your weapon for the correct type if you're fighting a major enemy only, and otherwise totally ignore attribute and class. Keep PP on weapons max.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9527020

iirc any weapon can only have one B/E/P and that is the default for that weapon type

Those values might only come into play when you combine stuff so other values carry over since weapons mix and match.
So a secondary non-active type will carry over in value in a future smithing combo where your blunt is turned into an edged, then the 6 from edged that your blunt weapon had will matter

This is why it's important to keep combining weapons and stacking these numbers as you go, and sometimes you'll have to have an intermediate weapon of a different type before you can combine it back into your desired type later on.

Like I said earlier, the best comparison is fusing demons in SMT games. Same as making sure certain spells/moves carry over across many fusions to your desired demon, the same is true here with types and affinities. Once you figure out (through experience) what weapon you're aiming for down the line, you can reverse-chart the necessary weapons to get to it and then optimize the combinations. If you do that you'll get a better resulting weapon than blindly mixing them, but you can clear the game without ever having to resort to that.

>>9526373
If you think about the game's concepts less how they're literally incorporated into the game with 1980s FDS software and more the overall game flow and hallmarks, I think Zelda 2 is definitely a precursor to the type of game that would eventually result in Skyrim
Because it's Zelda there are many streamlined elements, but it's still an expansive action RPG featuring a worldwide trek, exploring dungeons and powering up over time until you eventually rule over the once treacherous world thanks to your new weapons and abilities.
Just to tie in some things that are directly shared between Zelda 2 and Skyrim:
>overall game flow of walk around somewhat empty overworld, finding little caves as well as larger ones and dungeons that you either find goodies in or battle through, often beset on the overworld by roaming enemies, visiting towns to rest up and take in lore while making story progress
>both feature EXP and RPG mechanics that provide the player with plenty of opportunity throughout the game to customize their loadout and decide which stats they'd like to specialize in
>although Zelda 2 lacks most economy and loot systems due to streamlining, its palaces are still quite similar to plenty of Skyrim dungeon areas with many monsters to fight as you comb through the rooms looking for the reward (the ability to place the crystal and level up instantly in the case of Zelda 2)
This is just scratching the surface, basically just pointing out the most obvious shit. I could go on but my point is that Zelda 2's flow reminds me of the type of thing you'd see in many action RPGs to come. It's a game that feels ahead of its time in my opinion for combining those aspects of gameplay in the way it did.

>>9511906
>>9512063
I'm actually of the opinion that visual novels are better if Japanese isn't your first language.
I've read plenty of English visual novels and the experience can be somewhat unengaging, and they certainly don't feel like video games.
Reading a Japanese VN is much more involved. Looking up words, trying to learn them, and untangling sentences with twisted spaghetti grammar is quite stimulating. It honestly feels like playing a good puzzle game.
Like most puzzle games it can be really frustrating sometimesー I remember nearly pulling my hair out trying to figure out what the fuck 々 meant without knowing how to type or pronounce it. But overall it's mostly fair and mostly fun.
The extra time you spend with the story from your slow reading speed helps you get invested, and all the extra challenges you had to overcome really makes it feel earned when the cute anime girl you've fallen in love with tells you she loves you too.
In any case, ToHeart2 is an interesting title to look into even if you usually couldn't care less about visual novels. The PC version (XRATED) comes with a versus puzzle game and a shooting game, and the third entry Manaka de Ikuno!! comes with a trading card game and a full RPG. They're a lot of fun; it makes me wish more VNs had minigames.
If anyone here is interested in trying out XRATED, make sure you get the latest update, it adds a new character to the puzzle game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9507519
I think this website alone proves that people who are against achievements in video games simply lack skill.

It was only when they were first introduced in the PS3 / 360 era that cheevos sucked. The go-to example of this is probably The First Templar (way too easy) or Gran Turismo 5 (requires a retarded amount of dedication) not to mention all of the online-only trophies which were functionally impossible to get.

Nowadays, while there are a lot of games releasing solely for trophy hunters to get an easy platinum, most other achievement lists are designed by the developers themselves rather than a third party. In my opinion, if retro devs had access to cheevo software back in the day, the lists they would have made might be quite similar to these fanmade ones - barring glitches and 1cc autism, of course.

My go-to pick for proof of why RetroAchievements is fantastic are the coin challenges in SMB1. Even when you consult a level map to get every coin possible, ratchet scrolling means you have to be basically perfect. There's also the ironman challenge for SMW, or the extra hard cheevos for F-Zero X. It's also worth mentioning that the API's implementation is a fantastic training tool for indie devs since you have to dive deep into the code and tinker with lots of stuff just to make a functioning trophy.

There are definitely games which don't need achievements at all. Like, no one is ever going to fucking care you got 100% in NES Bubble Bobble. I still believe that it's a necessary step towards helping the younger generation get into older games. I hated Balloon Fight and Clu Clu Land until I tried getting cheevos for them, and it showed me that in spite of their lack of content these games can be enjoyed for an insane amount of time if you're going for specific challenges.

Is Jak 2 the biggest example of people disliking a game just from 2nd-hand info or only playing it for 5 minutes? All of the action, platforming, shooting, and driving from the original game was greatly expanded on, and pushed into a more difficult and interesting direction. Not trying to hate the original game either, I think it was a great showcase for the PS2 and a fun game by itself.

Because you're also not pushing the offensive when you have the opening.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
the breadbin C64 has unreliable, hot-running chips because MOS used an ancient and not very efficient 5-6 micrometer process from the 70s. the VIC-II in particular was quite power-guzzling as it's a very busy chip that has to perform all graphics functions, bus mastering, and RAM refresh, and its internal speed is 8Mhz. after three years of bungled attempts they switched to a modernized lower power 3 micrometer process which is what the C64C chips use.

so combination of some outdated tech and MOS not having especially good engineers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The VIC-II devotes 70% of its total die space to sprites because the aim was to overpower Atari with advanced sprite capability. However it also made the chip pretty inefficient and hot running due to the large amount of silicon needed for that. As for SID, Bob Yannes originally wanted six sound channels but didn't have time to implement that. So basically they wanted cutting edge audiovisuals but were constrained by cost limitations and not having the most modern manufacturing tech.

posts.name: Anonymous

The CPU was plenty fast, especially considering the higher clock rate and more powerful instruction set, registers, etc. It was also very similar to other CPUs and easy enough to pick up. The problem was you could get a 6502/Z80 from anyone for less and literally everyone knew how to use those.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: everyone was trying their own microprocessor in the early days; Fairchild, GI, and RCA's all went into different early game consoles but the 8080/Z80 and 6502 cornered the market due to luck and having a large software catalog.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
An overenthusiastic employee made a bunch of ridiculously difficult mazes for the game. They used them in the game just because they didn't want to hurt his feelings. Recognizing that the mazes are, in fact, ridiculous, they included a full guide with the game.
You can go through and draw maps of all the dungeons. This is how I like to do it. It's a kind of challenge that doesn't exist in RPGs anymore. For patient people, it's fun.
Or you can skip all that trouble and use the maps that were included with the game. It's still fun, although there is a bit of grinding. I kind of like the grinding.

If you've not played older actual dungeon crawl games, I would recommend trying to draw your own maps. It adds a significant flavor and investment that is very satisfying.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9527182
I've been doing this somewhat regularly for about a decade now. I had a few attempts at a single "game notes" book, but that has never materialized. One had loads of notes in it, but I left that with a previous relationship. One of my fondest memories was making maps of the crazy MOTHER / EarthBound Zero factories. The music in these games really burns into your brain permanently, and shapes how you feel. It is super cool to go back and reference old notes, though, on repeated playthroughs. The first time took forever, but this time it's your own previous hard work which allows you to coast more easily through.

The gun damage formula working the way it does owes a lot to the first Phantasy Star, which also had guns that did set damage and ignored enemy defense. They also struck whole groups instead of just single targets, so guns were useful to whittle down the 6+ enemy mobs you'd get at random. PS3 and PS4 largely did away with that and just treated them as regular weapons.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you want to beat the cpu, learn exploits that mog the AI
If you want to actually get good at fighting games you have to play against other human beings
Get on fightcade and start taking matches, first things you should focus on is not jumping all the time and not mashing when you recover from a knockdown

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9527635
This is the way. Playing AI past learning basic inputs mostly makes you a worse player.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9527620
>story mode
Literally the worst way to get better. The computer is gonna beat your ass before you learn anything because it can literally cheat (instant charge moves, instant dizzy escape, frame perfect inputs), and you're gonna get reckless looking for any openings you can get which will lead to bad habits and sloppy play.
Want to get better? 2P mode solo and beat up on the dummy 2P until you learn some basic combo strings (ex. Guiles bread and butter is Jump HP, down MP, flash kick). If you're too lazy to experiment look up combos for SF II Hyper Fighting' which is what snes turbo is based on. Play against other people.

tldr: playing the computer doesn't make you a good fighting game player.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The computer literally cheats and does shit like read inputs. Fighting them doesnt make you better at fighting people and can even give you some bad habits. It’s only good for seeing the story, but at least you’ll have learned some character’s attacks by now.

Older fighting games are harder to play, timings for combos and specials are way stricter. The ‘beginning’ of the genre is literally harder to play, especially since lots of games have slightly different strict timings.

If you want to get good at old fighting games, download fightcade, look up tutorial and advice videos, and play people.

Other anons will greentext me for recommending discord, but joining the discord group for a game will give you access to tons of players you can ask for game specific advice from. There’s a lot of dumb shit in games it’s better to just be told about than trying to figure out on your own. Someone on one of those discords can also give you the fightcade json autodownloader so you dont have to bother finding roms, definitely recommend asking around for it.

Oh and be a tier whore at least when you start out learning a game. You can always switch characters later, but finding the easiest high tier to play is the best way to learn the ropes of a game.

If you play a charge character, you can hold diagonal down back to charge both your back move-forward move and down-up move at the same time.

>>9527937
Not him but I'll try to explain since they're not wrong. Basically at high level fighters are almost all about mind games. Trying to second guess what your opponent is going to do so you can counter them. When you play against AI you build the muscle memory for doing moves and combos, but you don't build the mind games part because the computer doesn't fight the way humans do. So the longer you play, the more you get used to predicting and countering the AI. It's still an okay starting point but puts you at a distinct disadvantage when you move to fighting people.

So it's not like you can't get good at all playing the computer, but you'll get good much faster playing real opponents. And fighting people should be the goal always because it's where the real fun of the genre lays.

A mixup is "either A or B is coming in the next moment, and defending against both is mutually exclusive" (barring available option selects, which would go over your head)

Well, story-wise, Magus is only a shell of his former self after being defeated.

Gameplay-wise, he's actually underrated. First of all, he can wear the ultimate equipment combo of nova armor, haste helm and prism specs, which the girls can't. Also, his fire/light/ice-2 spells are actually stronger than the originals. NOT because he has higher natural magic power, but because his versions of those spells actually have a higher damage formula. So although his max damage isn't the best when everyone is maxed out, he has great versatility in damage type.

posts.name: Anonymous
