>>9531461
Magus sucks because he has no double techs. They're stronger and more MP efficient than techs of similar power at that point of the game.
>>9529480
Frog is great on paper, very versatile and fits into any party, however his techs have poor multipliers so his middle of the road stats mean he's consistently worse than other characters.
The whole reason why people give Robo the magic, and speed, tabs is because he's even more versatile and his skills have great scaling with magic even though he's not that much lower than Frog and Crono in magic.
>Lvl 30, no tabs
Frog, Heal: 21*6= 126 HP for 2 MP
Robo, Heal Beam: 18*10= 180 HP for 3 MP

I love this game and it's not like it's difficult but people usually find the most effective strategy and stick with that, that's why balance even in single player games is important. That's why so many doing a playthrough veer to Crono, Robo, Ayla set up, they just feel stronger, because they are.
>Lucca
Deals big damage but is completely useless against fire resistant enemies, even her double techs are pretty much all Fire elemental.
>Marle
Has healing but only single targets in a game where highest damage moves are multi-target, her damage is just as one note as Lucca
>Frog
Has his niche as a jack of all trades done better by a sturdier character, with a wider action pool and with better scaling

posts.sub: Experiencing Majora's Mask as a Kid
posts.com:
The first time I played The Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask it was newish. I was doing a sleepover at a friend's house.

I still feel nauseous just thinking about it. From the very first scene, Link and Epona isolated and weary in the eerie forest, Epona being taken, and pretty much everything to do with the Skull Kid. Being transformed into a shrub. The schizodemonic mask salesman and his scene's odd Battlefield Earth (2000) fuckery. Three days huh?

I step out into The oddly claustrophobic town with guards at every exit and holy moley the MOON wtf. Three days! Around this time my head is hurting sweetly. How do I escape this and see the new Hyrule Field? Ho, this gang of kids will help after a game of hide & se- YOU FUCKERS DO YOU NOT SEE THE MOON. They scatter, I search, the clock ticks, my hands begin to sweat. If I were really Link there'd be some casualties by now that Nintendo did not intend.

I find the last kid. I go down their clubhouse and meet a new dancing scarecrow. It is speaking gibberish even though I do not think that's what the developers intend. I hate the scarecrow, so much, and at this point I'm experiencing some nausea.

I move on and talk to old man at the observatory who, as everyone else I've met, lacks a proper sense of urgency. I look into his telescope and I see... that the clock is still ticking. Even while I peer through the scope the clock ticks. I don't know why I expected some moment of reprieve but I did, and it wasn't there. My mouth is dry and my bowels feel all twisted up. I run outside the observatory and see that I am trapped in a yard. I double check hurriedly as the clock ticks.

I break. I drop the controller, excuse myself, and go to vomit in my friend's bathroom- crying, snotting out, heaving, head splitting. Eventually I face my friend's mom to ask to use the phone to go home... She says NO! She tells me to go to bed. SHE WAKES ME UP AT 3AM TO HELP HER AND HER SON DELIVER NEWSPAPERS.

8/10 never playing again

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9531560
>what version should I play and on what system? which has the best looking font? should I play it on an lcd for the sharpest most crisp fonts, or were the fonts designed to be best displayed on a crt?
These questions are kind of beside the point. Infocom games were all implemented using a virtual machine (sort of like the Java virtual machine) called Z-machine, with a bytecode called Z-code. Infocom made all of their text adventures using Z-code, and then had an interpreter for each system they released it on. Every "port" of Zork will have the same Z-code file.
There's no real reason to use the original Z-code interpreters from Infocom, as the format has been completely reverse-engineered. There are modern interpreters for Z-code for whatever platform you want - Windows, Mac, Linux, Android.
Also get the PDFs of the original documentation. There's a manual, a "history" explaining the background of the game, and a few other things.

For emulation, I've been trying to find out what methods can be used for widescreen, without pop-in, culling, or other major issues. I was hoping you could help.

Let's start with dreamcast. The following games support 16:9 native (anamorphic):
Donald Duck Quakers, Rayman 2, Tokyo Xtreme Racer 2, Toy Commander, Toy Racer.

The following work in redream with the widescreen hack setting:
Crazy Taxy 2, Cyber Troopers Virtual On 2, DOA 2, Dolphin Blue, Fighting vipers 2, Ikaruga, MvC 2, Power Stone 2, Resident Evil Code Veronica X, Shenmue 1&2, Skies of Arcadia, Sonic Adventure 1&2.

The following work in Flycast, might work in redream, not sure:
Border Down, Cannon Spike, Carrier, Chaos Field, Charge 'N Blast, Chu Chu Rocket, Cosmic Smash, Crazy Taxy, D2, Death Crimson OX, Draconus, Dynamite Cop, Head Hunter, Heavy Metal Geomatrix, Illbleed, Karous, Maken X, Millennium Racer, Outrigger, Power Stone 1, Project justice, Rainbow Cotton, Red Dog, Re-Volt, Rez, Sega GT, Soul Calibur 1, Soul Reaver, Spawn Demon's Hand, Star Wars Racer, Super Magnetic Neo, Sword of Berserk, Time Stalkers, Virtua Fighter 3tb, Virtua Tennis 2, Wetrix, Zero Gunner 2, Zombie Revenge, Zusar Vasar

Does not work properly in widescreen:
Bangai-O, Capcom vs SNK 2, Confidential Mission, Frame Gride, Gundam Side Story Ashes, Jet Grind Radio, Napple Tale, Silent Scope, Slave Zero, Tomb Raider 4 Revelation & 5 Chronicles, Virtua Tennis 1

>>9527987
AoW seems to be written in Delphi, judging from the .dpl files (they're just dlls btw).
The UI uses the Visual Component Library that is based on Win32 API but adds a lot of custom controls. Looks like it was one of the easiest way to build good looking GUIs in Windows at the time.

As for VNs from that time, maybe they used the Windows API with custom engines in C or C++ or even languages like Hot Soup Processor.
Then engines like KiriKiri and Nscripter got popular.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
OP bothered me that much I'm going to briefly summarise the flow and design of each level in Einhander as a counter argument.

>Stage 1
>Metropolis background, moving billboards, neon signs can be destroyed, battle amongst skyscrapers, branching path leads to former city underground with unexploded warhead, final section takes place along highway

>Stage 2
>Wasteland stage, involves following an armoured train, train has multiple moving parts, some of which are destructible, action shifts from foreground to background, final section takes place in cave

>Stage 3
>Large vertical shaft inside industrial facility as play field whilst game still functions on horizontal field, broken up by Boss battle, returns to a vertical section with a lowering destructible ceiling that deploys enemies, stage continues horizontally, final section is in room that rotates according to Boss' weight

>Stage 4
>Stage introduces water with reflective surfaces and skimming effects, marine enemies appear, perspective changes to display Boss swimming underwater, proceeds to branching routes with moving elevators, final section includes destructible background and Boss battle takes place on surface after breaching

>Stage 5
>Spaceport stage with indoor and outdoor sections after the previous two stages taking place fully indoors, Boss is shown lurking behind background before battle, destructible background elements, final section takes place on climbing runway

>Stage 6
>Takes place entirely in the sky in which the objective is to destroy the rocket that has been launched within the time limit, Boss battle then takes place above the atmosphere, hidden Boss included

>Stage 7
>Space stage with turbulent movement to simulate effects of combat in space, assisted by lighting, enemies explode in different directions accordingly, Final Boss incorporates this with additional whirling camera

Not to mention the way each stage has its own atmosphere and various unique features.

It is, but I found it really cozy in a way. Reminds me of urban exploration and finding big, empty areas that are long abandoned and dilapidated. The emptier JSRF spots are basically an elaborated versions of the outskirts of the JSR maps

JSRF is a world built like a giant skate park. Both have their merits.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9518587
I'd make this top 10
1. Castlevania: Aria of Sorrow—must play for everyone. If you pick just 1 game, make it this one.
2. Rhythm Tengoku—best rhythm game I've played. Play if you like quirky games like Wario Ware and rhythm games.
3. Advance Wars—personally not a fan, but those who liked it spent hundreds of hours in it. Very addictive strategy game.
4. WarioWare—quirky and addictive, one of the more original games for GBA. If you've never tried it, do. If you did, still fun to see where it all started from.
5. Metroid Fusion—it's 2D Metroid, enough said. It's great despite some say it's not Super Metroid.
6. Mother 3—not a perfect RPG, but one many people want to play now. Play if you like Earthbound or want an RPG with plot.
7. Wario Land 4—some praise this is as pinnacle of GBA or even best platformer ever, others will write it off as good but ultimately weaker than the GBC ones. Regardless, well worth a try.
8. Mario & Luigi—actually very good RPG, only brought down by bing bang wahoo style and kinda whatever graphics.
9. Kirbies in general—always fun and worth a play. Play if you like Kirby, don't play if you're sick of platformers.
10. Mega Man Zero 3 & 4—decent games, but got pretty overrated recently as some "official canon classics". I beat them all, they're fun and good but not really masterpieces. Play if you like Mega Man X series and / or have played the other 9 games already.
Not on the list:
SNES ports, especially Mario ports—kind of obsolete in current day and age, maybe save for SMW as you can collect dragon coins in it, but that's it.
Pokemons—you either love them or hate them. If you love them, you probably know which ones to play anyway, and may prefer remakes.
Zelda: Minish Cap—it's more Zelda. Play it or skip it, it's alright if you want more ALTTP but thats about it.
Treasure games—no comment.
Mega Man Battle Network—one of those monster / card collect series that just goes on and on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Wario Land 4
Considered by many to be the pinnacle of the series (I prefer WL3), due to it's tight streamlining of controls, every level having more unique level design, and easy replayability due to it's short length.

>Metroid Fusion
>Metroid Zero Mission
2D Metroid created by the WL4 team. Fusion is a bit of a black sheep due to it's heavy narrative focus and linearity and Zero Mission is a remake of Metroid 1 but overall both games are still very good.

>Kirby & The Amazing Mirror
If you want Metroid Kirby. I love it though reading the in-game map will be frustrating, it's only real downside

>Game & Watch Gallery 4
If you want to replay old G&W classics but with Mario characters.

>Fire Emblem
>Fire Emblem The Sacred Stones
Still in my opinion the better of the Fire Emblems compared to the later entries. Also obviously the first two games released in the west. Good for a beginner's entry into strategy RPGs

>>9529034
Dolphin is a great example of an interface that actually needs to incorporate gamepad controls. There's no reason I need to use a mouse to select a game to play. There's no reason there's hotkeys like the screenshot or pause emulation button that have to be on keyboard instead of gamepad. Some gamepads even have mouse control built in, meaning if Dolphin had a proper console interface in the console emulation software, you'd only need a gamepad to have full control over it.

Retroarch does it correctly, as it is actually control agnostic insofar as an emulator can be. Since you're supposed to play these games on a gamepad, it supports gamepad controls itself. If I'm sitting on the couch, playing on my TV, I should not need to deal with this stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My recommendations for order play through and platform.

1. RE 96 or Directors cut (non-dual shock) PS1 on CRT
2. RE2 '98 PS1 or DC on CRT
3 RE3 '99 PS1 or DC on CRT
4. CODE VERONICA X (GCN or "PS2 Classic" version on PS4, stay away from the PS2 version and the HD MT Framework versions)
5. REmake PC or GCN + CRT
6. RE0 PC or GCN + CRT
7. Biohazard Outbreak Files 1+2 w/English patch on pscx2 with online via the outbreak resurrection server
8. RE4 PC + HD mod or GCN on CRT
9. RE5 GOLD PC
10. Revelations 1+2 PC
11. RE6 PC
12. RE7 GOLD PC
14. RE8 GOLD PC

Gits and shiggles if you really enjoy the series:
Umbrella Chronicles/Darkside Chronicles on Wii/Dolphin, Gun Survivor 2 w/ light gun or mouse

If you are a completionist:
RE Gaiden GBC and Gun Survivor JPN w/ lightgun

- Multimeter

>>9519535
I did get a desoldering pump, it was included with the soldering station as well as the solder itself. It's a 60/40 solder which I understand is the most common one. At this point, I would worry to much about the type of solder, the one you buy at the hardware store is going to be just fine, but if you must know, there is a type of solder material that includes flux inside the solder tube. From what I understand, you really want to get some flux so that you can break the oxidation surface in most metallic components and the solder sticks to it properly. I think that is more important.
And as far as removing solder goes, I'm going to use a desoldering pump, but you may also you those desoldering copper braids.

>>9523926
Took forever. Lots of fucking around with one of those dogshit solder suckers and wick. But there were still a few pins that connect to a large ground plain that I just couldnt get free.

I ended up getting it out with a fucking heat gun. I put the board chip-side down against an iron 45lb plate with the PPU over the center hole. I covered the motherboard with several layers of aluminum foil so that only the PPU pins were exposed. Then I heater it up a bit at a time and started tuggging on the PPU from the bottom underneath the iron plate until eventually I tugged it free

I was so scared that I probably just fried the chip... but it worked. Still going strong to this day

I wiped down the board with alcohol last night, as well as the connectors on the N64 itself, and just tested it again. No difference, game works as usual, but no data stays saved. I don't know if power is completely cut to the cartridge memory when the "Reset" button on the console is used, but using that instead of On/Off still led to memory being erased.
From further reading, the only two things I've discovered are:
1) multiple people in similar situations who said they had broken pin/trace connections to the chips, so they soldered wires directly from whichever pin(s) were disconnected to the appropriate chip. I'd have to spend a lot of time continuity testing and then finding a wire to put on there, which is more work than I'm willing to do, or;
2) I also saw a post from a guy saying that he owns two N64s, and one of them wipes the game data from cartridges he uses with it. If my problem is with the N64, that's possibly another can of worms, and would very likely be the same approach/solution as above. The only other game I have to test with is Mario Kart 64, which holds its data no problem. I don't think it utilizes the same CR2032 battery-based save system / PCB model, so I'm not sure if an N64-based fault would necessarily lead to data wiping on it anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9519589
>How do you solder these little fuckers?
one leg at a time. the other responses are fucking with you.
put solder+iron on a pad, slide the component into place (this is called 'tacking it down'), remove iron, solder the other side, and then clean up the first side if nits messy.
>Also how do you extract components without fucking up the solder pads
Use heat, not force. If you use force, shit breaks. Stuff will move with basically zero pressure when it's done right.
The exact method depends on the component (SMD vs TFT, simple two-leg devices vs complex multi-leg devices, etc) but for through-hole stuff you just remove all the solder using a good sucker or braid, gently moving the legs as you do so, and components will fall right out.
for small two-contact SMD stuff, you can usually just use lots of solder and a big tip to heat both sides at the same time and slide them off. components may get damaged due to heat when you do this, but the pads will be fine.
>(and if you do how easy is it to repair)?
Not easy. It's not an "experts-only" skill but it's tedious and not for beginners. practice on shit you dont care about because you WILL cause more damage than you fix the first few times you do it.

Why does DOS MIDI have such a distinctive tone compared to Windows or General MIDI?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9525067
MIDI is not a sound or sample set, it is a protocol by which messages are sent to an instrument to command it what note to play, for what duration, etc. A lot of DOS games were programmed with earlier sound chips in mind that used digital FM synthesis, but the Windows sound set is derived from Roland's MT series library, I believe. Sound cards of the 1990s used ROM to perform higher-quality samples, as opposed to synthesis alone.

>Dead or Alive 1
Use the Model 2 emulator.
>Dead or Alive 2
Use the Naomi emulator of your choice, whatever works for you.
In both cases, when MAME doesn't work you have to look around for a stand-alone emulator for whatever platform that arcade game was on. If it was basically a PC, then you use Teknoparrot or jconfig or w/e to act as a wrapper to make the game work on your PC. If it wasn't a PC under the hood, and there is no stand-alone emulator for the platform, and MAME doesn't run it, then you are shit outta luck.

Which version you want to play is mostly a matter of graphics. Some think the early release is more atmospheric, others prefer the redrawn versions. See pic related.

Either way, make sure to play a version that has the original still screen gameplay instead of freeroam. >>9518548
It was extremely significant at the time and is an important point on the timeline of how videogames progressed, so if you're interested in that which the people here who aren't just literally autistic and refuse to play anything they haven't played 1000 times before presumably are it's worth playing just for that reason. It's also a 3D art style that existed in the 90s where fidelity was starting to get to where things are recognizable and nice looking but still very artificial, it gives art like this a dreamlike quality and, at least to me, gives a powerful feeling of what the tech world was like generally back then, I can't look at myst without remembering stuff like the transition from dos to windows, the optimism, just that time period in general and I think that would come through even for someone without memories of that time. It's not a terribly exciting game, but it wasn't back then either. Play it to experience what we considered top of the line art and technology back then, don't expect it to be some kind of thrill lol. It's an adventure game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Myst
>original release
>pre-rendered images with video sequences
>lots of dithering on everything due to limited palette
Myst Masterpiece Edition
>graphical update from 8-bit color to 24-bit color so far less dithering used
>a dithered blue pillow turning purple since that was the color dithered to make blue, and the white pages inside the two books in the library have been tinted to match their covers, otherwise just improved graphics all around since used the same source material used to make the first game only without dithering down to 8-bit color
>added hint system for already easiest graphical adventure
realMyst
>3D remake of Myst, all graphics needed to be redrawn because of this
>added a grave on Myst island to match plot of the prequel books
>added another age accessible after beating the game that has another puzzle or two that is pretty meh overall, but hints at Riven
>dynamic weather/time system
>can be laggy even on modern machines due to engine being ported away from Glide to DirectX at the last minute and barely any optimization
realMyst Masterpiece Edition
>overhaul of realMyst with different engine and redone graphics
>a lot of shadows, details, and added stuff like the trees in that one age having a lot more leaves all the way up the trunk
>can look overly shiny and flashy, but still runs smoother than realMyst on modern PCs
>bloom and depth of field effects, trees move a bit in the wind
There's pretty much zero reason to play the original over Masterpiece Edition. If you aren't doing a 3D version, then that's the one to play. For 3D, you pick the one that you prefer the looks of. I prefer realMyst, others prefer the ME.

>>9526646
It's revisionist history. Myst came out in 1993, but it wasn't the #1 seller until later on. I remember reading a deep history on Myst that talked about how it didn't start selling really well until 95-96, and was even outselling Riven after it released. And by 95-96, most people had at least a 4x CD-ROM drive. CD's as a medium took off because of music CD's. They had far superior sound than cassette tapes, didn't wear out if you stored them properly, and you could skip to the song you wanted instead of fast-forwarding to get to where you wanted. Computers were already headed that way since 1.44MB floppy disks were turning game/program installs into 10-20 disk ordeals. That's what drove the adoption of the CD format. Sims and graphical adventures going with recorded speech instead of just text. Play the floppy disk version of Kings Quest 5 or Return to Zork, then the CD-ROM version. The pressure to get a CD drive was there before Myst released.

SS3 has a small roster and the fights end faster than in Virtua Fighter. It's a good game with a lot of nuance but it's obviously unfinished and in 2P you get under a minute of playtime on a credit.

>>9527775
If you're into Bubble Bobble and arcade-style games, check out Parasol Stars. It's a neat little game, and AFAIK plays best on the PCE. Only reason I know of it is because my friend and his gf showed up at my house with a big bin full of games (they were the gf's brother's, who left them when he moved out), including a TG-16 and a couple of games for it, which none of us had ever played. My bud's gf fell absolutely in love with it (she got really good at it, too), and we took turns playing it until we beat it, then replayed it several times until we got the best ending.

I've only really played a few other games for it since then, but I've been meaning to explore it further. I like how a lot of its games look and feel like souped-up, highly colorful NES games, and once you factor the PCE-CD games, it's even better. Unlike the Sega CD, it appears to have had a nice amount of high quality titles worth playing.

>>9522595
PS2 using ps1 controllers doesn’t mean DualShock 2 = DualShock 1
Ps1 being compatible with PS2 pads also doesn’t make the two controllers the same.

The way the DualShock 2 outputs is just straight up different than how the original pads work. They can however detect when they’re plugged into a ps1 (or ps2 in ps1 mode) and switch into a legacy compatability mode

Most ps2 games will also support the PS1 style controller protocols. But it wasn’t required by Sony later on.
Kingdom hearts 2 for example doesn’t work with DualShock 1s

There were a total of 39 baseball games released for the Famicom while there were just 20 NES releases. Some were localized Famicom games. RBI Baseball 2 and 3 were US-developed as was RCMVPBB but Australia's Beam Software did Bo Jackson Baseball. LJN's Major League Baseball was developed by NYC-based Enteractive Software.

The Famicom ones had various nifty gimmicks like the speech clips in Moero Pro Yakyuu and the Famista series had a dongle that attached to the cartridge and let you import your team from different editions of the game but NES baseball games never had this stuff.

>>9526440
Some time in the mid to late 2010s or whenever the fuck, a lot of character designs and whatnot of Mario characters started standardized, most notably Toads and certain enemies. While it's unclear if it is part of the mandate or just Nintendo being lazy/formulamatic, Mario games also followed a general theme structure that was rarely broken (grasslands first, desert second, beach third, etc).
The "Mario mandate" aspect mostly comes from the RPGs, primarily Paper Mario Sticker Star, where the team were told to not to make any new characters (Kersti being the lone exception). Some comments made around the time of Origami King's release suggest that this clause is still in affect in some way, with new characters needing to be very distinct. This standardization also carried on throughout other RPGs where the more distinct and out there Toad designs have been dropped, although NPC variety tends to be a slightly better due to using mooks/Yoshis as well as Toads.
Basically, all of this cemented Miyamoto as a control-freak mad man hellbent on removing the "soul" from the series. Whether or not he actually is in reality is up for debate.

They likely do, but wouldn't be relevant due to most Nintendo series being done in-house and having more consistency compared to the Mario games.

>>9526050
I echo the same sentiment that rings true for many who grew up playing this: he was absolutely TERRIFYING, but ultimately placed the player in an extremely unique position that taught them to overcome fear, and the value of empathy. Like, REAL fear and REAL empathy, that shit had profound impact on a lot of kids.

I like many swam away/turned off the game the first time. However, over the course of slowly working up the courage to approach him, you quickly find out he is good—not only a friend, but he is a victim. Clanker is abjectly suffering. He is literally enslaved and abused, rotting in the decay and neglect of his environment. This is why Clanker is special and unique—you are HORRIFIED of this fucker at first, but this slowly fading feeling of fear intermingles with increasing pity. It teaches children to gain courage through confronting fear, and to not withhold your compassion from people just because they are ugly, or seem off-putting or scary. It doesn't matter if Clanker is a giant metal shark with a face like a nightmare, you STILL need to get in there, be a hero, help alleviate some of the guy's suffering and extend some compassion to the poor fucking creature.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I was in elementary school when Duke 3D came out, but my mom bought it for me anyway.
Playing it at that time and at that age was mindblowing - levels that felt like real, actual places? A main character who drops one liners and comments on events as they happen? The ability to explore by crawling, jumping, and blowing open walls? Of course the big jiggling titties were nice and the swearing was funny, but even more astounding to kid-me was how immersive it felt. Doom had tried to depict locations, but at the end of the day it all felt less like space bases and hell castles, and more like abstract mazes with cool textures on the walls. Don't get me wrong, a lot of Duke's architecture falls apart under even a small amount of scrutiny, but nevertheless you could tell you were in a movie theater, a bar, a sushi restaurant, etc. It even made my little nerd brain think things like "oh wow, what if my doctor's hospital were a Duke level? You could hide behind the counters, run down the halls, fight aliens in the skybridge... It would be perfect!" as I went about my day.
I don't know if I'd even classify Duke 3D as one of my favorite games nowadays, but outside of maybe Pokemon, I can't think of many other games that really impacted me deeply enough to change how I thought about things in my daily life.

>>9525632
Blaster Master: Blasting Again was such a strange game, I have a theory on that.
>BA was initially planned to be a legit Metafight sequel in Japan.
>Sunsoft realizes they should rewrite the game for the west to fit the old BM canon.
>As a cost-saving measure, Sunsoft decides mid-development to make one script so they don't have to worry about regional differences too much and pay voice actors twice (note Jap BA uses Eng voices with subs).
>Older Kane becomes older Jason but they don't want any existing assets to go to waste and scramble with what to do about the older Jennifer they designed.
>Someone (probably from the American branch) chimes in that there is an equivalent usable female character in the BM continuity that they can use in her place.
>Older Jennifer is rewritten as an older Eve.
>By the time younger Eve was designed for BMZero Sunsoft had completely forgotten that she was ever supposed to be a redhead.
No particular evidence of this, just gut feeling.

It's really not. It appears like it is because the end result is usually correct English, but the quality of the translation itself is still really really bad. I have to translate some stuff from Japanese to English for my work before the new year rolls around (I'm not a translator, but I'm the only person in the company who is bilingual enough to do translation so I sometimes get stuck translating stuff) and I thought I could cheese it and run everything through DeepL since it's all super straightforward and grammatically correct with no slang or anything. Simple business language. Fucking nope, errors everywhere and I ended up having to actually translate it all myself. I was really disappointed because I was hoping that I could finish early with machine translation and then read a book or something but I'm pretty sure my ass would be in hot water if I turned in what DeepL gave me.

Btw, a ton of official translations (fan and official) are done by machines these days and that's a big part of why they're so bad, because machine translation is awful and the actual "translator" doesn't actually know the language so they're incapable of catching the mistakes when they happen.

Anyone who is actually fluent in Japanese and English would know that machine translation still has an extremely long way to go.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As someone who's followed the fan translation scene since the late '90s, which were focused on very well known titles (in those circles at the time) that just never made it overseas, like FFV and Star Ocean (the latter of which was hilariously controversial especially because DeJap blueballed everyone by claiming the lead translator's HD blew up back in 2001 or 2002 and asked for money lmao), I don't believe learning Japanese just to play video games is worth it especially in this day and age, mostly for a number of reasons.

Unless you specifically consume only Japanese media daily and use it proactively, you're not going to truly learn and comprehend the language and cultural history behind it, especially one that's so wildly different from English. That's not even getting into issues like nonsensical location jokes and references / skits that are extremely dated. There are lots of translators today, both by people who do it for a living or for fun or even AI / MTLs are getting in on the action, all of which pretty much renders that original "worth learning" part moot. On top of that, that's not even getting into the nightmare of localizations and the script purity question. Even with all of those compounded factors, there are people who still pushed through with it and there's a ton more people who know Japanese now than there was a decade or two ago, leaving a very saturated field of translators who are constantly fighting over rights to translate. There's also another thing in this thread that's worth pointing out too: most of the titles posted are either Sega Saturn, obscure PC-E or PS1/PS2 titles, the reason which is that the technology to actually inject and rewrite text, make sure it fits the boxes, etc. is a much more difficult task than translating the script itself wholesale. This is not even a new thing either, since you can find entire script translations on GameFaqs from the 90s and 00s long before the games even had working translation patches.

>>9523219
Linda Cube Again and Linda Cube Kanzenban are fifth gen remakes of the PC Engine CD title Linda Cube. A "psycho thriller and hunting RPG," protagonist Ken Challenger is chosen, along with his slightly crazy but devoted tomboy girlfriend Linda, to collect one male and one female of every species of animal on the planet of Neo-Kenya and upload them into a massive space ark before a giant meteorite destroys the planet and everything left on it in seven in-game years. As time passes, the weather and seasons change, and various animals and NPCs will only come out during certain conditions. The game features several novel systems, including dog party members which cannot be directly controlled. It also features three unique story scenarios which represent adjoined worlds and excellent art design from Japanese artist Cannabis. The first two scenarios are very violent and dramatic and the third is a joke scenario where everyone gets a happy ending.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9523268
Daikoukai Jidai 2 AKA Uncharted Waters: New Horizons, is a fifth gen remake of the cult classic Koei game, a pseudo-historical swashbuckling RPG which takes place during the Age of Exploration. Players can choose to play one of 6 different protagonists which feature different gameplay styles and intertwining storylines. The game has updated graphics and sound compared to the original console releases, which were also sadly censored when initially released in the West. It has an excellent score by Yoko Kanno and an unprecedented amount of freedom in how you approach playing the game, where the world map is a map of the original world.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9523320
Daikoukai Jidai Gaiden is a direct sequel/spinoff to Uncharted Waters: New Horizons. It only features two protagonists, allegedly so that they could go further in-depth with the storylines. It features extensive cameos from the original cast. One of the protagonists, Salvador, is the son of Khayr Ad-Din, AKA Redbeard, king of the corsairs and a major antagonist in the first game. His storyline gets much darker than those of the six protagonists in part two. The game features updated an updated tide and weather system which is meant to be more accurate than the previous game. Islamic regions will also not let you pray in their churches anymore, and Chinese ports are closed off to outsiders in an attempt to be more historically accurate. The coverart is by some famous furfag.

Cyber Doll is a yellow label (soft 18+) RPG for the Sega Saturn. Humans begin to fall apart and are forced to become cyborgs if they want to live. The game features cyberpunk imagery and an excellent soundtrack. The novel combat system features targeted combat where you can shoot out various parts of your cyborg foes, as well as a distance system where different weapons can only be used at certain distances. It features designs by Yasushi Nirasawa, famous for his work on Kamen Rider.

Wolkenkratzer is a 3D fighting rogue-lite game. A unique idea that has not been explored much since, you climb a tower fighting a random enemy from a certain tier on each floor. Before you open each floor door, the game gives you clues as to what monster awaits you, and you can change your equipment accordingly. After you defeat each enemy, you can search the floor for loot, although there is a chance you will have to fight another enemy instead of successfully finding anything.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You really just need to look at Castlevania 64's contemporaries to see where everything went wrong.

>Super Mario 64
>Ocarina of Time
>Final Fantasy 7
>Metal Gear Solid
>F-Zero X
>Star Fox 64

In a generation where virtually every 2D series worth their salt was making a successful transition to 3D, Castlevania fucked up massively. Even Legacy of Darkness couldn't fix it. People love to go on about its atmosphere these days, but back then, the game looked, played, and sounded like shit compared to everything around it. Worse, CV64 was one of the WORST games in the series at the time, released after Symphony of the Night showed what a modern Castlevania could look like in 2D. 64 failed on every meaningful level to deliver that same quality in 3D.

I hate that people like this game now. I really do.

posts.com: Has there been a game you started playing too late in life to truly enjoy? For example I played Unreal 99 for the first time a few months ago and it was amazing. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I was there, I can tell you.
It was fucking amazing, probably the most adrenaline-filled FPS multiplayer gaming I have ever experienced in my life. There were so many fucking servers, and you would often join a server with open slots only to be told it was already full. Didn't matter, there were always more servers with people on them. There were different classes of players out there. The noobs that didn't even attempt the singleplayer campaign who were target practice. The somewhat experienced players who've been playing for a while and don't know the maps by heart yet but aren't likely to be doing stupid things like standing still. The vets with good aim and who knew the maps who usually were around the top of the scoreboard.
Then there were the really good players who only used the melee weapon and the teleporter. You could usually spot the last group dueling each other in the skies of outdoor maps like it was a fucking DBZ fight, each trying to telefrag or melee the other without getting nailed themselves. If you ever got a kill on these guys, it was pure luck. 95% of the time you wouldn't even know one was there, you would just suddenly explode as one teleported into you.
It's sad all that remains today is one 24/7 vanilla Facing Worlds server where people just snipe 24/7, and a handful of heavily modded servers that aren't even really UT1999 anymore. I'm sorry you missed it anon, it was one of the best.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9530328
The one I missed out on was Delta Force: Joint Operations. I managed to play the demo and had great fun playing it online, but then I ended up working somewhere out in the middle of nowhere with no internet for about two years. By the time I got back online and got a copy of the full game, barely anyone was playing anymore. No more stock maps, all funky looking custom maps that are gimmicky and a pain to play. No vehicles on any of the custom maps either. A few years later, and the only people still playing are no-lifers who demand you join a squad and RP as a solder and show up to regular practices and blah blah blah or you can't even play on their server.
Really bummed about that to this day, because the demo was so much fun to play on the one map you could play online. Hopping on the minigun of a helicopter while someone flew it around and another guy hooked on the bench sniping at anyone trying to shoot us down, or racing around the ocean against three other guys in Zodiacs, just had a gameplay like Battlefield 1942 without being as janky as BF1942. The airduels in helicopters was always fun.

>>9530361
I'm sorry you missed it too. UT circa 2000-2001 was the golden age.

2.) people who never played them saw some 1v1 duel videos online and thought "ah so that's what they were like".

3.) they played quake or UT at it's peak when they were a dumb kid that didn't know better and never came back to it as an adult because of reason #1.

posts.com: Army in the earlier revisions, known as Campaign in later revisions. A simple DOS shareware game that is hard to search for due to how simple and generic the name is. You can still find it, it's just a bit tricky. Gameplay is simple, you get 5-6 dice(I can't remember the exact number) rolled on each turn, and you can move your units based on the dice you have. If you have a 6, you can move that unit 6 places. Then the opponent takes their turn. You have infantry, cavalry, and cannons, and the game has a very Civil War era feel to it. Nothing amazing, but I got it on a DOS shareware CD and played it a lot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Many. More people today appreciate Roguelike games than back when Rogue first came out, including retro ones like ADoM. I remember when SimCity 4 first came out, many people complained it was overly difficult to maintain a city and not as enjoyable as 2000 or 3000, now people consider it to be the best in the series. E.T. on the 2600 was considered absolute garbage at the time, now people have read the manual and understand how to play the game it's not considered so bad. Friday the 13th on NES also got left in the weeds, now people consider it a somewhat flawed action game. Starcraft Brood War has more balanced maps, more freedom in map creation, and far more UMS custom maps to play on than it ever has, along with less bugs than it did in the retro days.
Add in mods and hacks, and tens of thousands of retro games can be made better than they ever were. Saving in games that used to use passwords, mods that remove slowdown, mods that fix graphical and text issues, mods that fix bugs and glitches, and so on. Retro videogames are getting better by the day to the point even crappy games like Super Pitfall are getting overhauled into something halfway decent.

>I honestly don't know what appeals to so many people about this kind of back and forth game design.
Maximum player agency. The game has faith in the player not giving up on it, which makes the world feel very different than one whose highest priority is to stop players from quitting (most modern interpretations). It helps the believability of the setting.

>I feel like Metroid design is a relic from the original hardware limitations and has no other redeeming qualities.

You should probably not assume game design that differs from your preference is a result of hardware limitations if you can help it. It's as silly as the people that claim turn based games only exist because real time combat wasn't possible (there have always been real time games).

posts.com: Osomatsu-kun: Hachamecha Gekijou was one of four Mega Drive launch titles in late 1988 and the only one to not get an international release. Based on the Hachamecha Gekijou anime, which had just been rebooted from an original 1960s run in similar fashion to Q*Taro, another '60s anime/manga that was revived in the '80s and got a video game adaption on the Famicom--Hachamecha Gekijou, like Q*Taro, is not much known outside Japan and has never been dubbed or translated into other languages.. Control Osomatsu, the eldest of the six Matsuno siblings, on a quest to recover his kidnapped brothers from various wacky enemies. What was meant to be a technical showpiece for the new console however ended up being a little less than planned. Sega intended for Osomatsu-kun to use a 4 megabit cartridge but ROM shortages forced them to use only 2 megabits so some levels and other planned features were omitted.

PCE games were smaller because they had only one background layer and the CPU was 8-bit so code used less space while 68k instructions are physically larger as you can have 32-bit pointers and values. Instructions may be up to eight bytes in length

>>9525731
Facts about this pin:
Best selling pinball machine of all time. Sold 21070 units.
There was going to be an N64 game from Digital Eclipse that recreated this pinball machine, but it was cancelled in an early stage of development.
Pat Lawlor, this game's designer, retired just this year. His last game, which also came out earlier this year, was Toy Story 4 from Jersey Jack Pinball which sold out quite fast, ending his career on a high note.
The Weather Machine topper you see on top of a lot of Addams Family pins derives from a deleted scene from the movie. Of course, Williams didn't know the scene wasn't going to make the final cut of the movie when they built the topper.
There was a pinball machine based on the Munsters TV show released in 2019.
One of Pat Lawlor's early ideas for the design involved a dollhouse-type diorama in the backbox which would light up and do stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Addams Family games are okay.
Fester's Quest on NES is flawed, lot of bad decisions, and it could have been a better game, but as it is, it's alright. There's probably a romhack that patches a lot of the troubles the game has away, but even without it, it can be fun to play.
Addams Family and Pugsley's Quest on SNES are really great games. There's a lot to explore, loads of little secrets, and the sidescrolling is top notch.
Addams Family Value on SNES is an alright ALttP clone, but I personally didn't care for it.
Didn't play any of the other ones.

>>9526530
>>9527554
>>9525630


The issue is the amount of colors the machine could display on screen at once. You could palette swap to change 'em out on some things, but for video especially, this meant the Sega Genesis and all of its ilk could only have something like 61 colors on the screen at once. Better than the NES with its hack to get 25.

Then, the SNES had 256. Big upgrade. 3D0 could support 32,768 colors on screen at once. Amazing, but still not photorealistic. Today, we have millions on screen at once, allowing for things like High Dynamic Range settings, etc. HDR was to my mind first used in Half-Life 2 Episode 1? Maybe I am wrong.'

So, while people harp on about color palettes all the time in these retro circles, the thing that I think keeps getting missed is the size of those palettes being the most limiting factor. You can whip them in and out of memory to change every color on screen, but at the end of the day, you can only shade so much with 61 colors.

3D0 is the best old school, non-3d Road Rash. The best 3D Road Rash is the N64 version simply because the 4-player versus mode is absolutely fucking piss-pants, fist-fight, howling with laughter fun.

posts.name: Crystal Warriors
posts.com:
This a neat little game. It's a strategy RPG like Shining Force with an RPS elemental system, but when two units attack each other it turns into a mini Wizardry-style turn based battle. Each unit gets two turns, so can choose to retreat and give up your turn if the situation is unfavorable. There's also monsters you can recruit during battles which are useful for compensating for elemental advantages (e.g. a Fire type unit could use a Water type monster).

You recruit characters between rounds and there's even permadeath. It's not too difficult but can punish mistakes pretty hard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Hear me out... This was an experiment, and I think it went well.
I heard the Family Pocket was a fun and convenient device for the money and I thought "bullshit" but tried it because I was looking for cheaper gifts at the time and didn't want to setup and/or build a new device for the 50th time. It's not fun anymore.
I did take out the decoy cartridge and I did throw some other games on to test these silly Java emulators for NeoGeo and SNES, but that's it.
Metal Slug doesn't work. It won't pass the Yoshi's Island test, but I played Earthbound and Mario All Stars fine. Every GBC I've tried ran fine. All the NES and Genesis so far run fine.

It's all setup out of the box with a functioning UI in English, decent lists with boxart, easy save slot for each game, and instant on/off that (so far) seems to be about as safe as possible. I didn't swap the loaded SD for a better one yet so who knows? But six months of testing so far and no worries. I paid $25 for it. It looks and feels like a pickup and play toy and it is. Which I love.

I have several anbernic devices and so on, I'm not a pleb. I'm just sharing my findings on this. It's a really neat convenient affordable toy if you like the proposition.

(Also on a personal note, I love the sound. It isn't good although it has a vol wheel. But the mostly empty softer plastic case seems to smooth out all the bumpy squares and triangles in the sound waves of 8-16 bit games that make my ears thump uncomfortably without a great setup. I have this issue on my 351p with all settings possible tweaked. The smoothing resonance of the cheap case is a nice bonus for me.)
Thank you for liking and subscribing to my autistic review bastard blog
